title: 109_s1713
content: The Act may be cited as the "Iran Nonproliferation Amendments Act of 2005". The Director of Central Intelligence's report to Congress highlighted Russian entities supplying missile-related goods to Iran, India, and China, accelerating Iran's missile development. Vice Admiral Lowell E. Jacoby of the Defense Intelligence Agency also testified on this matter. The Director of Central Intelligence reported Russian entities supplying missile-related goods to Iran, India, and China, accelerating Iran's missile development. In testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee, it was stated that Tehran is likely to have nuclear weapons capability in the next decade. Iran has failed to comply with nuclear safeguards agreements and obligations. Iran has been found to be in noncompliance with its nuclear obligations under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. The International Atomic Energy Agency declared Iran's actions as noncompliant with nuclear safeguards, leading to questions within the United Nations Security Council. The executive branch has used authority to impose sanctions on entities violating restrictions related to the export of equipment and technology to Iran with the potential to contribute to weapons development. The executive branch has imposed sanctions on entities violating restrictions on exporting items to Iran that could aid in weapons development or are on US control lists for proliferation reasons. No determination has been made under the Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000 regarding Russia's stance on Iran's weapons programs. President George W. Bush issued Executive Order 13382 on June 29, 2005, blocking property of weapons of mass destruction proliferators and their supporters, targeting 4 Iranian entities. The order aimed to prevent the transfer of goods, services, and technology to Iran that could contribute to the development of nuclear, biological, or chemical weapons, as well as ballistic or cruise missile systems. Additionally, no Russian entity had made reportable transfers to Iran in the year leading up to the determination under the Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000. The Executive Order 13382 issued by President George W. Bush in 2005 targeted Iranian entities like Shahid Hemmat Industrial Group, Shahid Bakeri Industrial Group, and the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran for engaging in activities contributing to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Amendments to Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000 regarding International Space Station payments. Amendments to the Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000 exempt payments made by the United States Government for work related to the International Space Station before January 1, 2012. Amendments to the Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000 now include exempting payments for work related to the International Space Station, with reporting requirements for identifying Russian entities or persons receiving such payments. Since 2005, payments in cash or kind have been made for work or services under the Agreement Concerning Cooperation on the Civil International Space Station. Reports must detail the purpose of each payment and the President's assessment that it does not hinder US objectives to prevent missile proliferation. The curr_chunk discusses measures to prevent the proliferation of ballistic or cruise missile systems in countries supporting international terrorism. Amendments to the Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000 are proposed to include Iran and Syria. Amendments to the Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000 now include Syria in addition to Iran. Amendments to the Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000 now include Syria, expanding restrictions on transfers to or from Iran and Syria. Amendments to the Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000 now include Syria, expanding restrictions on transfers to or from Iran and Syria. The Act's short title has been changed to the Iran and Syria Nonproliferation Act, with updated definitions to include foreign governments and entities. The Iran Nonproliferation Act of 2000 has been amended to include Syria, now known as the Iran and Syria Nonproliferation Act. Any reference to Iran in the Act now includes Syria as well. The curr_chunk is about the roles of the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the Vice President of the United States as President of the Senate.
